Module discret¶

The module discret basically contains the functions for the color image proccessing, like converting the fromat of the image into another, for example, convert an image in RGB to a Greyscale format.

This is the list of all of it:

discret.histogram(i)[source]¶

Histogram of grey values of the L image i

Parameters:i (tuple) – Image (Type, Matrix)
Returns:A list of the 256 values (0 upto 255) of the grey scale values of the L format image
Return type:list 
>>> histogram(('L', [[255, 255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255, 255]]))

discret.luminance_img(i)[source]¶

Transforms a RGB image into a L image using rgb_to_lum(i) for each pixel tuple in RGB

Parameters:i (tuple) – Image (‘RGB’, Matrix)
Returns:The an L image format from an RGB image
Return type:tuple (‘L’, Matrix) 
>>> luminance_img('RGB', [[(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)], [(255, 255, 255),
(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)], [(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)]])
('L', [[255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255]])
>>> luminance_img('RGB', [[(255, 0, 255), (255, 255, 255)], [(0, 0, 255), (255, 0, 255)]])
('L', [[170, 255], [85, 170])
discret.rgb_to_bn(i)[source]¶

Transforms a RGB image into a 1 image format using luminance and histogram, with the image converted into a grey scale format (L).

The function goes through each pixel of the L image and compares it with a certain value to know if it is part from the Backgound or Foreground.

In this case we’ve decieded that the medium value to know if a L pixel is black or white is the 128, if is greater or equally to 128 is a white pixel and is a black pixel if not.

Note

We’ve had troubles in the making of the project because of the Otsu Thresholding Method Algorithm, it is supposed that using this algorithm should give us the medium value to know if the pixel it is a part from the Background (black) or Foreground (white).

But we’be translated the code that it is written natively in java to python and it didn’t work, even though that the code is almost exactly the same.

Parameters:i (tuple) – Image (‘RGB’, Matrix)
Returns:The an 1 image format from an RGB image using luminance_img(i)
Return type:tuple (‘1’, Matrix) 
>>> rgb_to_bn(('RGB', [[(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)],[(255, 255, 255),
(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)], [(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)]]))
('1', [[255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255]])
>>> rgb_to_bn(('RGB', [[(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)],[(255, 255, 255),
(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)], [(255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255), (255, 255, 255)]]))
('1', [[255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255], [255, 255, 255]])
discret.rgb_to_lum(pixel)[source]¶

Returns the luminance level of a RGB (R, G, B) pixel using a simple formula:

The luminance of a pixel in RGB is (R + G + B) / 3

Parameters:pixel (tuple) – Pixel
Returns:The luminance of the RGB pixel
Return type:int 
>>> rgb_to_lum((255,255,255))
255
>>> rgb_to_lum((255,0,0))
85
